The connexion between suffering and sin was universally believed in, and even exaggerated, when St. J ames wrote 3 as is evident from our Lord’s words about the Galileans, whose blood Pilate mingled with the sacrifices, and 6150 from the question of the disciples about 1116 man who was born blind. St. Paul asserts that many were punished with sickness and even with death for irreverence in receiving the Eucharist. The J ewish proverb quoted in my note to the effect that ‘ a man could not recover from sickness till his sins were forgiven' 15 quite in accordance with our Lord's procedure in healing the sick of the palsy, where the words ί8011, thy sins are forgiven thee' preceded the command ‘Rise up and walk’ 3 and both enable us to understand why confession and forgiveness are introduced here in the instructions given for the healing 01 1116 sick.

There seems, however, to be a certain want of consecutiveness in the language 01 St. James.
